Expectation1: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation1: A patient is recovering from a recent surgery and requires more careful assistance to move and get dressed.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I stood by Mr. Harris’s bedside, carefully helping him sit up. His stitches were fresh, and every movement needed my full attention. As a nursing assistant, I knew my patients depended on me for their comfort and safety. Today, though, my mind wandered. My friends were finalizing their plans for Hajj, and I had finally saved enough to join them. It was a dream I’d carried for years, a pillar of my faith, and now the opportunity was real. But Mr. Harris needed me—he trusted me to help him heal, to be present and attentive. My supervisor had already mentioned how short-staffed we were this month. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me: the sacred call to pilgrimage, and the immediate, human need before me. My heart ached with longing and guilt, torn between my duty to my faith and my responsibility to my patients. I paused, hands trembling slightly, unsure which path I could bear to leave behind.
